citations.narrative:
On June 23, 2024, a 10-year-old spayed female Mexican Gray Wolf, ID # F1363, was found injured in her enclosure,
which she shared with two six-year-old intact male Mexican Gray Wolves. Husbandry staff indicated they observed
multiple wounds on the animal and tissue hanging from her lower abdomen. The female was sedated and evaluated by
veterinary staff followed by general anesthesia and exploratory abdominal surgery. Due to the severity of the wounds and
poor prognosis, she was euthanized by the attending veterinarian. A necropsy was performed, and the cause of death
was reported as, “…Humane Euthanasia due to attack and damage caused by other wolves housed in her enclosure.”
According to facility staff, the wolves had been living in the same enclosure for approximately 5 years with no previous
signs of incompatibility detected.
Animals may suffer from stress, injury, or death when housed with other animals with which they are or become
incompatible.
The facility must ensure that animals housed in the same enclosure are compatible, and that animals are not housed near
other animals that interfere with their health or that cause them discomfort.
Corrected at the time of inspection on January 29, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
